KOCH NITROGEN COMPANY

Walton Terminal ET-8
Walton, IN

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)


Introduction and Policies

Koch Nitrogen Company (KNC) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  KNC?s management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the terminal, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the terminal and planned changes to improve safety at the terminal.


Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Walton Terminal is one of many facilities owned and operated by KNC that supply anhydrous ammonia to the Midwest farming area where it is used primarily as a fertilizer. At the terminal, anhydrous ammonia is delivered by pipeline and stored until it is loaded on to trucks for distribution.  
 
Anhydrous ammonia is the only toxic substance regulated under the Risk Management Program (RMP) that is present at the Walton Terminal in amounts above threshold quantity.  The terminal is classified as Program Level 3 under the regulation. 


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by KNC.  These high standards include:

?Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
?Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
?Operati

ng and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
?Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.


Prevention Program

The Walton Terminal is operating under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees, and emphasis on safety has helped avoid any serious chemical release accidents over the last 5 years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include: 

?Minimizing the possibility that flare combustion of ammonia vapors would be interrupted by having a continuous pilot. 
?Minimizing the possibility that combustion of ammonia vapors would be interrupted during a power failure by having a backup generator for the flare. 
?Minimizing the possibility of overfilling by having level alarms on storage tanks and bullets.
?Providing emergency shutdown buttons at the truck loading area that can be activated by KNC personnel or the truck driver in case of an ammonia release.
?Preventive maintenance and testing of vessels through the Mechanical Integrity program helps to ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.
?Requiring trucks to have a brake interlock system that helps prevent a truck driver from driving away before the loading arm is properly disconnected.
?Installing ammonia sensors in the process areas and on the property to detect ammonia and activate the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) monitoring system if the threshold for ammonia is exceeded.
?Monitoring level alarms and pressure in process vessels through SCADA to help prevent a release of ammonia.
?Providing annual truck loading training to

ensure driver safety.
?Minimizing the possibility of overfilling the bullet with relief valves, reverse check valves, and a motor-operated valve on the inlet pipe to the bullet that closes automatically.
?Installing cameras and motion detectors that alarm at a central control room in Wichita to alert that intruders may have entered the facility. 
?Monitoring the level of liquid ammonia in the bullet on a continuous basis.
?Loading of trucks occurs only when KNC personnel are on site and can monitor activities.


Five-Year Accident History 

Within the last five years there have been no chemical release accidents that resulted in onsite injuries, death or property damage or offsite impacts.


Emergency Response Program

    The terminal will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary for the Walton Terminal with the Walton City Fire Department.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Cass County Sheriff, the Cass County Emergency Management Agency and, as appropriate, Memorial Hospital at Logansport, the utility company Miami/Cass REMC and the Indiana State Highway Patrol.  The Walton Terminal Manager is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions.  A specific Emergency Response Plan for the terminal is in place and that plan has been coordinate with local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program, coupled with the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

?The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
?T

he Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
?The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program. 

Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the terminal include:

?Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the terminal is periodically evaluated for improvements.
?An ongoing dialogue with the Cass County Emergency Management Director or his designate will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops. 

All interested citizens or community organizations are encouraged to contact the Cass County Emergency Management Director for the latest information on emergency response for the county.  The terminal coordinates its response capabilities and personnel with those of the county on an ongoing basis.
